metadata.case_name: Sarjoo Prasad & Ors. v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Appellants' mother purchased the property known as the Crove situate on Station Road at Patna on 18 September, 1944.
Appellants' mother made a trust deed in the year 1946 in respect of the property in favour of the appellants.
The property was requisitioned by the Government of India with effect from 17 July, 1942 under Rule 75A of the Defence of India Rules.
The Government was in possession of the property until the Government decided to acquire the property in the year 1953.
The Central Government gave notice under section 7 of the 1952 Act to acquire the property. The property was acquired on 11 September, 1953 under the 1952 Act.
The Government offered to the appellants a sum of Rs. 2,47,990/- as a valuation of the property acquired. The appellants claimed Rs. 18,00,000/- as the valuation.
Under section 8(1) of the 1952 Act the Government appointed the District Judge, Patna as the sole Arbitrator to determine the amount of compensation payable to the appellants.
The Arbitrator awarded compensation under section 8(3)(b) of the 1952 Act on 25 May, 1956.
The appellants preferred an appeal against the award of the Arbitrator under section 11 of the 1952 Act.
The Patna High Court dismissed the appeal on 13 January, 1961, holding that section 8(3)(b) of the 1952 Act applied and upholding the award.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the compensation would be determined under clause (a) or (b) of sub-section (3) of section 8 of the 1952 Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Defence of India Act, 1939 and the Rules made thereunder ceased to be effective on 14 February, 1946. There was no order of requisition under the 1952 Act. For the purpose of determination of compensation of the property under the 1952 Act the property could at best be held to be requisitioned when the 1952 Act came into existence.

respondent_arguments.text: Though section 8(3)(b) of the 1952 Act was applied by the Arbitrator, in substance the Arbitrator gave effect to the provisions of clause (a) of section 8(3) of the 1952 Act.

court_reasoning.text: The contention that the year of requisition should be 1952 when the 1952 Act came into effect is unsound. The Requisitioned Land Continuance of Powers Ordinance, 1946 (Ordinance No. XIX of 1946) provided that notwithstanding the expiration of the Defence of India Act, 1939, all requisitioned lands shall continue to be subject to requisition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The property continued to be in possession of the Government under orders of requisition dated 17 July, 1942 and was not released.

court_reasoning.text: Thereafter the Requisitioned Land Continuance of Powers Act, 1947 came in place of Ordinance No. XIX of 1946. The Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Ordinance 1952 came into effect on repeal of the 1947 Act. Finally, the 1952 Act came into existence. These provisions and in particular section 24(2) of the 1952 Act show that the property became deemed to be property requisitioned under section 3 of the Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The requisition continued through the chain of laws.

court_reasoning.text: In Union of India v. Kamlabhai Harjiwandas Parekh this Court held that the mode of determination of compensation prescribed in section 8(3)(b) of the 1952 Act is arbitrary and bad.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The award made pursuant to section 8(3)(b) cannot be sustained.

court_reasoning.text: The award expressly made under section 8(3)(b) does not in substance give effect to clause (a).

holdings.text: The appellants are entitled to compensation in accordance with the provisions contained in section 8(3)(a) of the 1952 Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Kamlabhai Harjiwandas Parekh & Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that section 8(3)(b) of the 1952 Act is arbitrary and bad

statutes_cited.relevance: Continued requisition after expiry of Defence of India Act

statutes_cited.name: Requisitioned Land Continuance of Powers Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Replaced Ordinance No. XIX of 1946 and continued requisition

outcome.summary: The judgment of the High Court which upheld the award of the Arbitrator is set aside. The Government will have to act in accordance with the provisions contained in section 8 for determining compensation payable to the appellants under clause (a) of sub-section (3).
outcome.relief_granted: Direction to Government to determine compensation under section 8(3)(a) of 1952 Act

key_quotes.text: "The result is that the award which was made in the present case pursuant to the provisions contained in section 8(3)(b) of the 1952 Act cannot be sustained."
